Combining Formal Controls to Improve Firm Performance
items.abstract: <jats:p>Formal controls are an essential part of organizational design, and are theorized to positively influence organizational performance. Mello and Hunt ([2009] <jats:italic>Transportation Journal</jats:italic>, 48:20â39) were the first to suggest using formal controls to influence truck drivers' behavior. Extending the salesperson control literature, they documented an underresearched method of formal control that we term technology control, whereby firms use onâboard and communications technology to influence drivers. We build on their work by investigating the contingent effects of formal controls that influence the behavior of truck drivers and thereby influence the operational performance of firms in the U.S. motor carrier industry. Our work integrates the monitoring aspect of agency theory with the theory of operant conditioning and the theory of psychological reactance to develop a rationale for hypothesized contingent effects of formal controls on motor carriers' operational performance. We collected primary data pertaining to the controls used to influence truck drivers' behavior from a large sample of U.S. motor carrier firms. The results of our analyses using nonlinear structural equation modeling suggest a complex set of relationships between formal controls and operational performance. Our results shed light on scenarios where using technology to monitor driver behavior can result in positive and/or negative organizational outcomes.</jats:p>

title: Direct monthly highly active antiretroviral therapy supply â a method to increase patient's adherence and outcome. Experience of one AIDS centre in Israel
items.abstract: <jats:p> In Israel, antiretroviral therapy (ART) is available (at local pharmacies) without cost. Nevertheless, poor adherence, especially of immigrants from Africa, leads to a high rate of treatment failures. Our study looked whether direct monthly ART supply in our AIDS centre has an effect on adherence and outcome. A total of 385 HIV (clade C) immigrants from Africa that were treated with ART for >2 years prior to the initiation of the study were evaluated. During the first 2 years, ART medications were supplied by local pharmacies. Thereafter (next 2 years), all patients received medications, monthly at our centre. Adherence, immunological (CD4) and virological (VL) outcome at the end of the two study periods were determined. At baseline, only 75% of the patients attended more than 90% of scheduled visits with 57% treatment adherence. Virological failure (VL >40 copies/ml) was observed in 53% of the patients. As a result of our intervention (2 years of direct monthly ART supply), visits and treatment adherence significantly increased (90% and 84%, respectively; pâ<â0.001). Concomitantly, virological failure rate significantly dropped to 28% ( pâ<â0.001). Direct monthly supply of ART is a relatively low-cost mode to improve patient's adherence and immunological/virological outcomes. </jats:p>

items.abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Objectives</jats:title><jats:p>The aim of this study was to investigate the impact of myocardial area supplied by the coronary artery on fractional flow reserve (FFR).</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>Various factors other than the degree of epicardial stenosis influence the physiological significance of a coronary artery stenosis.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Methods</jats:title><jats:p>A total of 296 coronary lesions in 217 patients were analyzed by quantitative coronary angiography and FFR. Myocardial area supplied by the coronary artery distal to the stenosis was evaluated by angiography using a modified version of the Alberta Provincial Project for Outcome Assessment in Coronary Heart Disease (APPROACH) score.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>Percent diameter stenosis of the coronary lesion was 57âÂ±â15% (meanâÂ±âstandard deviation). FFR <0.80 was seen in 132 (45%) lesions. FFR was significantly correlated with minimum lumen diameter (râ=â0.584, P <0.001), percent diameter stenosis (râ=ââ0.565, P <0.001), lesion length (râ=ââ0.306, P <0.001), and myocardial supply area (râ=ââ0.504, P <0.001). Multivariate logistic analysis demonstrated that minimum lumen diameter (odds ratio [OR]â=â0.031, 95% confidence interval [CI]â=â0.013â0.076, Pâ<â0.001), lesion length (ORâ=â1.038, 95% CIâ=â1.009â1.069, Pâ=â0.001), and myocardial supply area (ORâ=â1.113, 95% CIâ=â1.079â1.147, P <0.001) were independent determinants for FFR <0.80.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title><jats:p>FFR, which is the index of physiological significance of coronary artery stenosis, is influenced by myocardial supply area distal to the stenosis as well as by its own minimal lumen diameter and lesion length. Â© 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p></jats:sec>

title: Opening the black box: outcomes of interactions between arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) and nonâhost genotypes of Medicago depend on fungal identity, interplay between P uptake pathways and external P supply
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigated the physiology that underlies the influence of arbuscular mycorrhizal (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AM</jats:styled-content>) colonization on outcomes of interactions between plants. We grew <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>edicago truncatula</jats:italic>â<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A17</jats:styled-content> and its <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AM</jats:styled-content>âdefective mutant <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>dmi1</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> in intragenotypic (two plants per pot of the same genotype, x2) or intergenotypic (one plant of each genotype, 1â+â1) combinations, inoculated or not with <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">R</jats:styled-content>hizophagus irregularis</jats:italic> (formerly <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>lomus intraradices</jats:italic>) or <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>igaspora margarita</jats:italic>. We measured plant growth, colonization, contributions of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AM</jats:styled-content> and direct <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> uptake pathways using <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:sup>32</jats:sup>P</jats:styled-content>, and expression of plant <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P<jats:sub>i</jats:sub></jats:styled-content> transporter genes at two levels of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> supply. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A17</jats:styled-content> (x2) responded positively to inoculation only at low <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>. The response was enhanced with 1â+â1 even at high <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> where colonization in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A17</jats:styled-content> was reduced. With <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">R</jats:styled-content>.âirregularis</jats:italic>â<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> uptake by the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AM</jats:styled-content> pathway was unaffected by <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> supply, whereas with <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>.âmargarita</jats:italic>, the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AM</jats:styled-content> pathway was lower at high <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>, and direct uptake higher. Gene expression varied and was unrelated to <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> uptake through the two pathways. There was no evidence of plant control of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> uptake via <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">R</jats:styled-content>.âirregularis</jats:italic> at high <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content> but there was via <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>.âmargarita</jats:italic>. Importantly, growth responses of plant genotypes grown alone did not predict outcomes of intergenotypic interactions.</jats:p>
